key_facts: Sea temperatures around the Great Barrier Reef are the highest in 400 years.
The high temperatures have occurred over the past decade.
The warming poses an existential threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
Researchers used coral cores to trace historical environmental conditions.
The warming is linked to recent mass bleaching events.
Coral bleaching is caused by extreme heat.
Coral bleaching leads to algae expulsion.
Algae are critical for coral survival.
Bleached corals may die if high temperatures persist.
Ongoing climate change could permanently alter the reef.
The Great Barrier Reef is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Scientists urge stronger global climate action.
Scientists call for the reef to be designated as endangered.
The endangered designation would highlight the reef crisis.
Researchers say hope remains if global warming is limited.
Collective action can help protect the reef.
